Don't we already know that 5 goes into 11 twice? Just do 11 - 5 = 6, then do 6 - 5 = 1, then stop as you know it goes into 11 twice with a remainder of 1. So why does the CPU need to go into negative to calculate that? Unless the negative is a good condition to use as you can say the loop is what decides how often a number goes into another number. So really the computer runs from 0. So 11 - 5 = 6 (0), 6 - 5 = 1 (1), 1 - 5 = -4 (2) and you know that when you get into negative, you've gone too far. So then you add the positive number back again to get to positive which is 1 which is the remainder. Since the computer doesn't intuitively know that 1 is the remainder, then going into a negative could be a good way of getting the computer to go back when it goes too far to get back the same answer. So that's why computers aren't as intelligent but they're really bloody fast.

I learned more from this lady in 12:17 minutes on YouTube than I did in engineering in college. In Computer Engineering (were I was supposed to entirely learn C+ over a weekend, and NO, I'm NOT kidding) Nobody told me a thing other than that there are "Registers" that things get stored in, the assembler turns it all into machine code (and the machine language underneath the hood is written by Magic Elves) and that's that and (much like in The Spy that Shagged Me) When I asked, I should essentially "just sit back and enjoy the show." I didn't. Not one damned bit, and you should excuse the pun. I need to know everything on a fundamental level...Right down to the atoms in the doping of for example, a Transistor, progressing to the "on" and "off", at the base/gate of the transistor  and build up from there. I don't drive a car or a concept without knowing what's under the hood... (or in this case... Bonnet ;-))  That's how I think: It's how I roll, know what I mean?  So... I just stayed with Heart  Transplant Nursing as a career instead since I already had a degree in that... What I always wondered is if you could have a built in set of "check" instructions so if there is an error, say a bit flip or something,  you could instantly clear all of the registers and just reload everything all over again and move forward, or would that be way way too slow and cumbersome? Time went on. Today, I play with Arduinos. And still practice Nursing. All the Best! DE W8LV BILL

There is not an easy answer to this question. In the example used in this video you need a single fetch-decode-execute cycle to execute a single instruction. Modern CPUs can actually execute multiple instructions per cycle. And not only because they contain multiple cores. Even a single core can execute multiple instructions per cycle. Modern CPUs are highly pipelined which means that while one instruction is being decoded, the next instruction is already being fetched. Also modern CPUs are superscalar, which means that they contain multiple ALUs and the CPU can dispatch multiple instructions simultaneously to different ALUs.

Fundamentally they don't. Data can be interpreted as programs and programs can be interpreted as data. It is the job of the programmer to jump to the correct memory address. But that is the source of many security problems. If you can get the computer to execute the data that you entered as a program, that is bad, because now you can do pretty much anything you like. But modern CPUs make that harder to do because they allow the operating system to mark blocks of memory as read-only or prevent the CPU from executing certain blocks of memory.

​@Johnathon C Yes, you can write assembly into data and execute it. But if you store the code in memory that you explicitly allocated as "executable" there is no problem. That is, unless you allow a user to write arbitrary data into this memory. However, it should not be possible to execute code that you stored in memory allocated with "malloc" or "new" (I have actually never tried it). If that is indeed possible that might be a giant security problem (depending on which privileges your program is running on).

The easiest answer is kinda, but when dealing with this kinda of instruction set you are better off comparing it to Java or C/C++, really any compiled langauge. All that means is first you need to compile the code then execute it. If you use an IDE such as eclipse or visual studio then both are done when you press run. The job of the compile phrase is to break down your code to a lower level langauge which in tern will break it down to the type of instructions you saw in the video. In a langauge like python which is interpreted the way the computer runs it is very different. But that was just a design choice by python which we dont need to worry about since its a layer of abstraction

Crash Course: Computer Science truly is a thing of beauty.  Despite staying with the series since the first World History, this is the first time a field that I've actually studied at an undergraduate level is covered. I have a bachelor degree in System Science, which means I've done mostly high level programming and business analysis. I have however taken a few, basic courses in low level computer science. Crash courses if you will ;)  The courses I took were all kind of sheit, it's quite a heavy subject for people more used to social sciences, yet it was awfully administrated and the lecturer sucked. I powered through it but it always felt like a disappointment, since the subject really did interest me and I would have liked to take it on with a little more enthusiasm.  Looking at this I can't help but feel like this is how it's supposed to be done. It really covers all the essentials, without dumbing anything down, and yet manages to make it all crystal clear and understandable. It all adds up to a series that actually engages me in a way that I wish I would have back when I actually studied this.  When it comes down to it, I don't think it's the quirky graphics, occasional pop-culture references or lighthearted presentation that makes up the "entertainment" part of well made edutainment (though don't get me wrong, I appreciate that too), but rather the fact that it's presented with clarity, competence and enthusiasm, with a structure that makes it feel meaningful and leaves you wanting more.  So thank you to all involved with making this, and all the other shows. What you do makes a difference, and you guys really are the best at it.  Sincerely /A proud patreon

Read about RISC and CISC CPU architectures. First designs hardwired all the instructions (RISC): it is fast but you can't extend the instruction set. Now CPUs contain a very basic set of hardwired instructions and keep the rest (and how to break them down into these the hardwired ones) in an internal memory (CISC).
No, a CPU does not melt when it crashes. It just abruptly stops running.

There are no official definitions of various unrecoverable abnormal conditions that a computer goes through. Also, an application program or background process may "crash" or "freeze" but the operating system may continue to run or it may initiate a graceful shutdown. Operating system manufacturers have their own terminology as well. Unix, Linux, and macOS developers call them "kernel panics". Windows developers call them "stop errors".   These are some of the generally accepted definitions I've used. If the display on the screen does not change, but the cursor is still blinking or the mouse pointer can still be moved, then I would say the computer is "hanging". If the display on the screen does not change and the cursor stops blinking and the mouse pointer cannot be moved, then I would say the computer is "locked" or it is "frozen".   Many different conditions can cause a computer to "lock" or "freeze". The clock not working is only one of them. Other conditions can be the CPU executing an invalid instruction or op code, accessing a memory location that does not exist, a memory chip malfunctions, an expansion board malfunctions, a paper clip falling into the inside of the computer causing a short, or pulling an expansion board out of a computer while it is running, In the case of the Mark II computer, Grace Murray Hopper's associates discovered a moth stuck in a relay impeding its operation. So the next time the computer was not working, they would say that there is a bug in the system. So utility programs that are used to troubleshoot a computer are called debuggers.

Also, side note, if you think making the number being subtracted negative would make it infinite they you forget about overflow, it would eventually overflow and wrap around to become negative or crash from the overflow

It crashes. More modern processors have functionality to just to a trusted instruction location to handle the error gracefully, but in that case, the application that ran the invalid instruction would still usually crash. If the trusted code had an invalid instruction, then you get a double fault (a crash within the crash handler). If the double fault handler crashes, the whole machine gives up, throws a triple fault, and reboots.

In most architectures, the compare instruction is just a subtraction that throws away the output. It's easy to simulate by storing one of the registers to memory and loading it back after the subtraction.

In my college we made from scratch a PIC16F84 in a circuit simulator and even programed the microcode on the control unit (the one who converts the opcodes into firing the correct wires controling ALU and registers), then we compiled actual C code to run in our cpu.  The instructions that made us crazy was the jump, wich in this case has two of them: Bit Test File Skip if Clear and Bit Test File Skip if Set (BTFSC and BTFSS). The opcode adresses one byte in memory and then a single bit in that byte, then based on it's value it performs the skip or it just continues. the BTFSC does the jump when the the bit is zero and the BTFSS does the jump when the bit is one.

They just have more complicated fetch phases and the instruction register made larger to accommodate the largest instruction. The length of the instruction would either be stored in an additional register, or recalculated during the decode phase.
But that would put the PC in an inf. loop since it would always subtract by zero, with the number never becoming negative.

The issue is  that, if the number that gets put in B is zero(or negative), A will never become negative. the way to fix it is very simple if you have a jump if zero, and only slightly more clunky if you don't You just put this in-between your register loading, and your loop LOADC (memory address containing a negative one) ADD B C JUMP IF NEGATIVE->(wherever your end of program is) (the rest of your code) If B is anything but a positive number, this breaks you out of the program

Right. If you want to get technical about it, it was a modulo routine, which as stated in the video could be modified to also provide division, since it basically does the division as part of the routine. Kaos and Maxi explain it well, though I might add that a negative divisor would eventually overflow and halt in a real computer.  I didn't get my Engineering CS BS for nothing!

C and C++..... yeah, high level...
C and C++ ARE high level languages (well C++ is anyway, C you could argue either way)
Like, C was certainly high level in 1980, but you'd have to be mad to suggest it's high-level these days.
wat. Of course it can. High/low level is relative to other languages. When languages with better abstractions come along, the potential for languages to become "low level" instead of high arises.
Interpreted languages, like Python or Perl are even better. They're easier to write and usually less prone to cause BSoD, at least for me.

C was once touted as "portable assembler" code but it isn't that hard to write apps in C. C++ is another animal, orginally just a superset it has evolved into something else, and a much easier language to write large applications in, though still an unforgiving steep learning curve.
C and C++ are considered third-generation programming languages.

I don't know what "definitions" you are referring to. Examples of the different generations have been: First generation: machine code Second generation: assembler code Third generation: FORTRAN, COBOL, BASIC, APL Pascal Fourth generation: SQL, Pick Access

RaymondHng I mean, cool, I don't disagree with your examples. But the only distinguishing factor between the generations is the degree to which they're imperative-declarative, which isn't the only factor influencing a languages classification as low/high level. By mentioning that C and C++ are considered to be in the same generation isn't exactly relevant.
Then are you saying that C and C++ are different generation programming languages?

RaymondHng I'm saying one is a relatively high level language and I'm saying one is absolutely not. I don't think generation is a useful qualifier, but yes, I'd say they are the same generation, despite having wildly different levels of abstraction.

"High level languages" are a class of their own and don't stop being in the class of languages that interpret the programmer's input just because something more efficient is developed. You simply don't understand what the term means.  Machine languages — interpreted directly in hardware. Assembly languages — thin wrappers over a corresponding machine language. High-level languages — anything machine-independent. System languages — designed for writing low-level tasks, like memory and process management.  HIGH LEVEL LANGUAGES: High-level languages, like C,C++, JAVA etc., are more English-like and, therefore, make it easier for programmers to “think” in the programming language. High-level languages also require translation to machine language before execution. This translation is accomplished by either a compiler or an interpreter.
Then what about virtual assembly languages that are machine independent?
They're low level languages. They deal with a abstract machine in a low level manner.

Wrong. The Pick operating system is written in Pick assembly language, a machine-independent assembly language. It originated on minicomputers and was ported to mainframes (IBM System/370) and microcomputers (IBM PC/XT) and it has been running vertical-market business applications since the '70s.
LLVM is a machine independent low level language. It was literally called Low Level Virtual Machine once upon a time.

You know, no-one actually uses this classification system in the industry, right? If you turn around and say that C is a high-level language you'll get laughed at. Categorising anything that is machine-independent as "high level", while not inaccurate (if you're comparing them to machine/assembly languages), fails to provide meaningful distinction between, say, C and Haskell, which have immense differences in the levels of abstraction they provide, despite both being machine independent. That's why I'm saying that "C used to be a high level language but isn't anymore". Because new languages have come along that make its capabilities for abstraction look laughable.

Yeah. I haven't heard the term "Fourth generation language" used in about 20+ years. The whole 'generation' thing died from irrelevance. There are higher and lower level languages, C at the lower end, things like python and ruby towards the upper end, and different types of course, functional vs procedural vs imperative. It's a rich ecosystem. As always choose the right tool/language for the job.
jbz3 actually, we are not that far. We are adding abstraction layers to the CPU, but not to the memory. A couple levels and we could be talking about the stack, heap and memory pointers
down 20 and 1 to the left...
jbz3 Actually many processors have single instruction multiple data (SIMD) instructions specifically for operations like matrix operations.
J B Actually vectors are a programming concept similar to arrays or lists
we're already there. mul, adds, loads, stores.

Those often come as libraries with  data structures and a set of functions. So your abstraction leveks are: 1. Function calls  2. Higher level programming language  3. Compiler  4. Data structures/non native data types  5. The concept of an programming interface  6. Libraries.  And you could come back to this topic when discussing computer graphics and using the graphic card for calculations.  All this doesn't even include the many levels of running a non-bare-metal programm in a multitasking, reactive, resource managing operating system. Which you would do if you want to do something useful with your math.

Perhaps you mean GPU optimized vectors and matrices?  A GPU is essentially one of these CPUs with a limited instruction set, but with thousands of them instead of just one.  The cores would each grab a value of your matrix/vector and perform operations on it, then spit out the final result.  The CPU would have to send the data down to the graphics card somehow (which is achieved with PCI lanes), and the graphics card would have to send it back, or just push it out to your display.
Data structures and objects are fun.
@jbz3  Yeah, a 512-bit SIMD op-code can concatenate two 4x4-matrices composed of 16-bit floats in a single cycle of a single core, i.e. we're already there, complexity aside.

Computer Engineer here, if computers ever drop to less than 50% magic it means you have skipped over some fundamental concepts lol. There are only certain levels of abstraction you can think of a computer in. To completely understand a computer you need to also understand the quantum aspects of semiconductors, transistors etc. You need to know about the voltage filtering systems embedded in the computer since AC is really a moving sine wave which can be in different phases depending on what device they went through, you need to know all the electrical components and the firm/software that control them and how those systems can fail and how to troubleshoot that and the hardware languages that describe each piece which is fundamental to how they work along with the higher abstract level programming languages like Java and python and how their Network  adapters work etcc lol. I worked years in IT, spent my teens programming and wrapped up a degree in computer engineering and still sometimes I fix something and my client goes "How the hell did you fix that?" and there are more times than you'd think where I shrug, the senior engineer shrugs, the computer shrugs and the computer god shrugs too. It's just magic.
